steps.text: Pave dusty roads and maintain lawns.
Ensure proper drainage.
Position lighting away from buildings.
Reduce bird harborage and outside food spillage.
* Nonchemical Management:
Use rodent, insect, and bird traps.
Maintain housekeeping and implement pest monitoring programs (e.g., pheromone traps).
(Rodents) Maintain bait stations.
( Insects) Use insecticidal baits and approved insecticides near breeding sites.
( Birds) Use chemical repellents and avicides where appropriate.
**Buildings:**
* Preventive Maintenance:*
Rodent-proof all openings.
Screen windows
Eliminate cracks, crevices, and ledges
Block bird access to ledges
Locate equipment off the floor or sealed to it
* Nonchemical Management:
Keep all areas free of loose materials
Clean structures and equipment frequently
Use electrified grids inside for insect attraction
Start by looking in obscure places using a flashlight to detect insect trails or mouse footprints in dust
Observe suspect stock by spreading it on a flat surface and watching for movement
Inspect areas most likely to produce results, such as under and inside equipment
Suspect any unaccounted-for voids in equipment or structures
Observe employee actions and in-plant practices
Reward good sanitation to encourage plant-wide cooperation
Perform visual inspection
Focus on high-risk foods (oldest, from a high-risk firm, in warmest areas)
Visual inspection also helps identify open packages and poor sanitation
Inspecting bagged commodities
Identifying pests
Determining the extent of a problem
Evaluating a treatment method
In dusty areas, use pitfall traps or traps that deflect dust.
Place traps on the outer perimeter of a facility.
Start with a wide grid (e.g., one trap per 100,000 cubic feet).
Visually search areas where the most insects were captured.
Look for increases in numbers from one period to the next.
Look for cleared paths outdoors or greasy runways indoors
Identify rodent signs: Rubmarks, Burrows, Tracks, Urine
Store products on pallets away from walls
Create a strip of gravel around buildings
* Rodent-Proof Construction:
Seal all openings larger than 1/4 inch for mice and 1/2 inch for rats
Use rodent-resistant materials like hardware cloth, sheet metal, and concrete
Pay attention to doors, windows, vents, drainpipes, foundations, and utility lines
* Tracking Powders:
Place toxic dust in runways
Rodents ingest it while grooming
Select a proper bait
Offer unpoisoned bait for several days to overcome shyness
Place tamper-proof bait stations
Use tamper-proof bait stations to protect bait and prevent access by children and non-target animals
Place stations along walls and runways
Use Compressed Air Sprayer for crack and crevice, spot, and general sprays
Supply clean air from an external source or a tank
Perform daily negative and positive pressure checks
Wash respirators regularly and store them in a clean, protected place

constraints.expression: Wet processing areas require acid-proof or brick floors
constraints.text: Wet processing areas require acid-proof or brick floors

constraints.expression: Wall materials like concrete, brick, or tile should be sealed and easy to clean

constraints.expression: Hollow panel-type walls must be well-sealed to prevent them from becoming insect quarters
constraints.text: Hollow panel-type walls must be well-sealed to prevent them from becoming insect quarters

constraints.expression: Roofs should be smooth and free of standing water
constraints.text: Roofs should be smooth and free of standing water

constraints.text: Pitch and gravel or corrugated metal roofs can harbor insects
